Body:
In Russian, like in Basque, Finnish or Estonian, verbs can have two types of object: the Genitive or the Accusative modes. The Genitive case in such structures is actually a partitive (which is rendered in English by partitive marker 'some', like 'I have some friends' or 'do you need some water?'; hence, the partitive-governed verbs.

Verbs of the first type can have an object in both cases: взять деньги (Acc.) or взять денег (Part.), both are grammatical meaning 'to take some/the money.

Verbs of the second type can have the verbs with Accusative objects (which is more or less similar to the most European languages where an object is distinguished by a case ending): выбрать деньги (to choose the money) is grammatical, while * выбирать денег (to choose some money) is not. It does not have anything to do with the perfective/imperfective types of the verb we can say понабрать(ся) слов ('to take/to borrow (for oneself and by oneself) some words), which is grammatical, while * понабираться слова (pl. object) is not.

My question concerns the Russian verbs of the third type. The verbs of this group either have a special prefix, which determines the event structure as described by a verb, as in понабрать(ся), or they don't have such a prefix.

In the latter case, the verbs have no prefix, yet the grammatical structures require a partitive object only: коснуться травы (to touch [some] grass) is grammatical, while * консуться траву is not. It is not exactly a partitive, either, because an action taken upon a smaller object with a smaller surface follows the same pattern: to touch the key (on a keyboard) shall be коснуться кнопки (sg. object), and not * коснуться кнопку.

This is not a distinction by perfective/non-perfective types, because касаться травы VS коснуться травы (to touch [some] grass) are equally grammatical. However, we cannot say * коснуться траву. It does not have anything to do with animate/inanimate nouns, either, because the only grammatical option is to коснуться медведицы (to touch a she-bear), not * коснуться медведицу.

It is not related to the transitivity-intransitivity, since not all reflexive intransitional verbs take a partititve ending, e.g. like in вернуться в дом (to return [oneself] in the house) with accusative argument.

It is not related to the reflexivity/non-reflexivity, either, because in Russian the only grammaical argument for ждать (to wait) is partitive, although the verb is not reflexive.

The question shall be, is there a general rule for choosing a partitive object, and what are the other verbs of this type in Russian? Is the third group a Russian peculiarity only, or is there in other Slavic languages a similar pattern for verbs taking partitive objects only?
Title: Russian verbs demanding partitive arguments only: main rule/semantic range?
